metadata.title: Nano-zero-valent iron and MnOx selective deposition on BiVO4 decahedron superstructures for promoted spatial charge separation and exceptional catalytic activity in visible-light-driven photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Hazardous Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jhazmat
Nano-zero-valent iron and MnOx selective deposition on BiVO4 decahedron superstructures for promoted spatial charge separation and exceptional catalytic activity in visible-light-driven photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system Xin Dua, Tianyu Zhaoa, Ziyuan Xiua, Zekang Yanga, Zipeng Xinga,⁎, Zhenzi Lib, Shilin Yanga,⁎, Wei Zhoua,⁎
a Department of Environmental Science, School of Chemistry and Materials Science, Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, 150080, PR China bDepartment of Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Harbin Medical University, Harbin, 150086, PR China
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Photocatalysis Fenton reaction Selective deposition Magnetic separation Assembly
A B S T R A C T
Novel nano-zero-valent iron (Fe0)/MnOx/BiVO4 ternary magnetic assemblies are fabricated through hydrothermal and photo-deposition strategy. The assemblies are characterized by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, photoluminescence, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. Fe0 as a reduction cocatalyst are deposited on surface of monoclinic BiVO4 decahedron supersturcture. Meanwhile, MnOx as an oxidation cocatalyst is selectively anchored on oxidative {110} facet of BiVO4 by photodeposition. The photogenerated electrons and holes can be transmitted to Fe0 and MnOx, respectively, which favors the spatial charge separation. The adjunction of Fe0 significantly enhances light absorption, and forms a photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system simultaneously. The assemblies with narrow band gap of 2.10 eV display an exceptional photocatalytic activity, and the visible-light-driven photocatalytic degradation ratio of 2,4-dichlorophenol and Bisphenol A are up to 95.4 and 91.4%, respectively, which are several times higher than that of pristine BiVO4. This is ascribed to the selective decoration of Fe0 and MnOx favoring the spatial charge separation, and the photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system enhancing degradation. Moreover, the superior magnetic property due to Fe0 decoration realizes magnetic separation of catalysts, which is favorable in practical applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, environmental pollution, especially water pollution, has become increasingly serious [1]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to solve current environmental crises facing modern society. Currently, the semiconductor-based photocatalytic is one of the most prospective solutions to solve environmental issue by effectively converting solar energy into chemical energy [2–5]. These promising photocatalytic materials such as TiO2, graphene, KNbO3 and transition metal dichalcogenide have been extensively studied by many researchers [6–9]. Recently, the Bi-based semiconductor materials, for instance, Bi2O3, BiOI, Bi2WO6, Bi2MoO6 and BiVO4, have fascinated extensive advertence [10–14]. Among these materials, monoclinic scheelite structure BiVO4 has been the most extensive research in water splitting and environmental remediation for its strong visible light response ability, with narrow band gap of ˜2.4 eV and advisable band edge locations [15,16]. However, BiVO4 still has some shortcomings, such as the poor segmentation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and comparatively inferior capability in utilization solar light. Distinct morphologies of BiVO4 were prepared by different experimental methods to improve these disadvantages, such as nanoparticle, nanosheet, decahedron, etc. [11,17,18]. The photocatalytic conduct of BiVO4 is related to its construction, the main exposed faces of the decahedron BiVO4 at different positions correspond to {010} and {110} facets, in which photogenerated carrier can be preferentially dissociated and congested on the {010} and {110} facets, respectively. Thereby achieving efficient charge separation is due to the driving strength engendered by the distinct energies of the conduction band and the valence band of the two facets [19–22]. Certainly, it is also necessary through other means to stimulate charge separation and solar utilization of BiVO4. In particular, the addition of cocatalyst can effectively improve the
photocatalytic efficiency of the photocatalyst [23,24]. The cocatalyst mainly has two types of reduction promoter and oxidation promoter [25]. On the whole, noble metals transfer electrons, which can be used as the efficient proton reduction cocatalysts such as Au, Ag, Pt, Pd, etc. [26–28]. Some metal oxides homologous to the artificial photosynthesis catalyst can personate as the oxidation cocatalysts, such as Fe2O3, RuO2, MnOx, IrO2, etc. [29–32]. Due to the collaborative effect of prompted consumption of photogenerated electrons and holes, and the oxidation and reduction cocatalysts deposition on semiconductor photocatalysts can evidently heighten its photocatalytic activity [33]. For BiVO4, photogenerated holes can selectively accumulate on the {110} side to preferentially carry out oxidation reaction, so metal oxides cocatalysts can selectively deposit on the {110} facets of BiVO4 [19,34,35]. The oxidation cocatalysts can selectively deposit through the Eq. (1) (Mm+ stands for metal ion):
Mm+ + xH2O + (2x-m) h+ → MOx + 2xH+ (1)
The photogenerated electrons and holes can be further transmitted to these cocatalysts for the surface catalytic reactions [36,37]. In order to better enhance the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4, MnOx was selected as the oxidation cocatalysts deposition on the {110} facets. Manganese oxide not only has favorable oxidation properties to provide superior synergistic effects, but its energy band level structures can be well matched with BiVO4 [34,38]. The photocatalytic efficiency of a single photocatalytic system can
still be improved by coupling other effective catalytic techniques [39–41]. In the circumstance of degrading organic pollutants, Fenton technology in the existence of Fe species and hydrogen peroxide have been extensively studied as effective advanced oxidation processes (AOP) [42,43]. The philosophy of the Fenton reaction is that the H2O2 reacts rapidly with dissolved Fe species producing a large number of active species, which oxidize organic compounds [44]. Nano-zero-valent iron (Fe0) has been abroad used as substitutes for iron oxide species or Iron cation in catalyzing oxidants owing to its environmental
friendliness, briefness of apply, and low expense [45–47]. In addition, nano-zero-valent iron can be converted into divalent iron particles to form Fenton system in the existence of hydrogen peroxide [48]. The well-known Fenton reaction can rapidly generate numerous active oxygen species through the Eqs. (2) and (3):
Fe2+ + H2O2 → Fe3+ + %OH+OH− (2)
Fe3+ + H2O2 → Fe2+ + %OOH + H+ (3)
One of the advantages of the photocatalytic coupling Fenton system is that the automatic generation H2O2 on the interface can substitute the extra added H2O2, due to the photogenerated electrons fast seize the dissolved oxygen in the water intermediary to form hydrogen peroxide [12,49]. Nano-zero-valent iron in a photocatalytic system, H2O2 and the free hydrogen ions ability to convert Fe0 particles into Fe2+ thereby forming Fenton reaction [50]. Magnetic separation is another merit of nano-zero-valent iron in the Fenton system, which makes the catalyst to be reused with no difficulty. At the same time, nano-zero-valent iron can effectively enhance the light response of materials and improve the utilization of sunlight [51]. The ground-breaking coating of nano- zerovalent iron on the surface of BiVO4 can form a stronger Fenton system than iron oxide, and make the material magnetic, thereby promoting the separation performance of the catalyst and improving the application value. In this paper, a novel Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 ternary magnetic assemblies are fabricated by hydrothermal and photo-deposition tactics. The selective deposition of MnOx and nano-zero-valent iron evidently boosts the photocatalytic activity of BiVO4. The study of the construction of BiVO4-based photocatalytic coupling Fenton system is very rare, and the innovative introduction of nano-zero-valent iron-based Fenton reaction and co-oxidant MnOx is very valuable, so this novel study is very necessary. Photocatalytic activity of the catalyst is appraised by photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol and Bisphenol A by simulated solar irradiation. The excellent catalytic activity is ascribed to the selective deposition of nano-zero-valent iron and MnOx promoting the spatial charge separation of BiVO4. Moreover, the mechanism of visible-light-driven photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system for the Fe0/ MnOx/BiVO4 assemblies was also proposed. The prepared Fe0/MnOx/ BiVO4 has novel, low-cost, non-toxic, easy-separating characteristics, and has excellent photodegradation efficiency, so that it has a good application prospect in the field of photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants. In addition, this work provides a new tactics for devising high-active visible-light-driven photocatalyst in future.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Synthesis of BiVO4
sections.text: BiVO4 was prepared by a hydrothermal reaction. In detail, Bi (NO3)3·5H2O (3.5 mmol) and NH4VO3 (3.5mmol) were dissolved in 20mL of 1.5M HNO3 solution, and recorded as solution A and solution B, respectively. Under magnetic agitation, the solution B was added into the solution A drop-by-drop. After stirring for 20min, the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 2.0 with the 2M ammonia solution. After mixing evenly, the orange precipitate was aged at the bottom of the beaker. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 100mL of Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 200 ℃ for 24 h in an oven. After hydrothermal reaction, the obtained yellow powders were collected and washed with distilled water and ethanol for three times, and dried overnight at 60 ℃.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Synthesis of MnOx/BiVO4
sections.text:
The MnOx/BiVO4 composite materials were synthesized by a photodeposition technique. The MnSO4 was employed as the manganese source and KIO3 as the electron acceptors. 0.3 g of BiVO4 powders
dispersed into 50mL of 0.01M KIO3 solution. Then, added 1.5 mL of 0.5 g L−1 MnSO4 solution. Under continuous stirring, the mixture was irradiated by PL-XQ500W Xe lamp (λ≥420 nm) for 3 h and then washed with ethanol for 3 times and dried at 60 ℃.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Synthesis of nano-zero-valent iron (Fe0)
sections.text:
The nano-zero-valent iron particles were prepared by using the li-
quid-phase reduction method. Typically, FeSO4·7H2O (10mmol) was added into 100mL of ethanol/water solution with a bulk ratio of 3:7 in a 250mL of three-necked flask. Under the N2 atmosphere, 50mL of 0.2M NaBH4 solution (also ethanol/water) was added step by step within 3min. The black particles formed immediately in the mixed solution. The process was kept 30min after the complete injection of NaBH4 solution to guarantee the completion of reaction. Then, the obtained black powders were vacuum filtered and washed with ethanol and vacuum, finally dried at 50 ℃ overnight.

sections.heading: 2.1.4. Synthesis of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly
sections.text: The Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assemblies were synthesized via a solvothermal approach. Under nitrogen gas, 0.3 g of MnOx/BiVO4 sample and 0.01 g of Fe0 particles were dispersed into 60mL of deoxygenated deionized water with assistance of ultrasonication for 60min. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 100mL of Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was heated at 120 ℃ for 3 h. Finally, the as-prepared samples were vacuum dried at 50 ℃. For comparison, the Fe0/BiVO4 was synthesized under the same conditions in the absence of MnOx (Scheme 1).

sections.heading: 2.2. Photocatalytic activity test
sections.text: The detailed photocatalytic activity test is in supporting information.

sections.heading: 3.1. Phase structures and morphology
sections.text:
The crystalline structures of BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 are examined by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique (Fig. 1a). All samples display the similar tendency that well
fit the card, indicating the as-prepared samples are monoclinic scheelite-type BiVO4 crystal structure with high purity (JCPDS No. 75-1866). It is noteworthy that the relative strength of the diffraction peaks situating at 18.68° (110) and 19° (011) pull back significantly after the addition of MnOx. It indicates that the {110} facets of the BiVO4 is successfully deposited by MnOx. Plainly, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the MnOx are not inspected because the amount of MnOx deposited by light is very small. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 1a, the diffraction peaks at 44.7° is discovered in the sample of Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4, which can be allocated to {110} crystal phases of the nano-zero-valent iron, and demonstrate the successful fabrication of assembly. Furthermore, contrasted with BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/ BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 illustrate the cognate diffraction peaks, indicating that the existence of the MnOx and nano-zero-valent iron cannot affect the crystal structure of BiVO4. In addition, magnetic separation can implement photocatalyst re-
cycling by utilizing an adequate extrinsic magnet on the magnetic unit in the composite structure [52]. The magnetic properties of the asprepared samples at unequal phases (BiVO4, Fe0, Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/ MnOx/BiVO4) are inspected by trick of vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) analysis. As shown in Fig. 1b, the magnetic hysteresis loops of Fe0, Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 have representative ferromagnetic identity with saturation magnetization of 179, 130 and 123 emu g−1, respectively. The magnetic capability of BiVO4 is infinitely close to zero. Although the magnetism of the final sample is relatively weakened, the assemblies still possess high magnetic, which promote the efficient separation of the catalysts. To visually probe the microstructure and morphology of as-pre-
pared samples, the homologous scanning electron microscope (SEM) images are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, the BiVO4 is truncated bipyramid morphology, with a width of 3–4 microns, and display relatively incisive edges and smooth surface. Furthermore, the main exposed faces of BiVO4 at different positions correspond to {010} and {110} facets [19]. TEM image of BiVO4 is shown in Fig. 2f and its appearance can be observed. Respective cumulation of electrons and holes at the {010} facets and the {110} facets, owing to the conduction band edge of the {110} facets of BiVO4 is 0.42 eV higher than that of its {010} facets, and the valence band edge of the {110} facets of BiVO4 is 0.37 eV higher than that of its {010} facets, which lead to the selective deposition of manganese oxide on the {110} facets instead of the {010}
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration for the formation of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly.
facets [21,22]. In Fig. 2c, the {110} facet of BiVO4 becomes coarse, due to the deposition of sponge-like MnOx. However, the {010} face of the simple is still smooth, indicating that MnOx is selectively only deposited on the {110} facet. The morphology of Fe0/BiVO4 is shown as Fig. 2d. After adding Fe0, BiVO4 is completely covered by the Fe0 particles. The state of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 (Fig. 2e) is similar to the Fe0/BiVO4, all exposed crystal faces of MnOx/BiVO4 are completely covered with Fe0 nanoparticles, and the surface becomes rougher. Fig. 2g shows the TEM image of Fe0. Because Fe0 has poor dispersibility, the nanoparticles in the image are agglomerated. The MnOx deposited on the {110} facet is also shrouded by the Fe0 particles, and cannot be observed obviously. In addition, the TEM image of the final sample is shown in Fig. 2h.

sections.heading: 3.2. Elemental analysis
sections.text:
To certificate the Fe0 particles and the MnOx uniformly loaded on the surface of BiVO4, the elemental mapping analysis in the Fe0/MnOx/ BiVO4 composite material is shown in Fig. 3. As can be seen that Bi, V, O, Fe and Mn elements are evenly distributed in the setup, and the manganese element is mainly existed on the {110} facet of BiVO4. This also demonstrates that the morphology and structure of Fe0/MnOx/ BiVO4 is constituted of BiVO4, MnOx and Fe0, and the MnOx is selectively deposited on the {110} side of BiVO4. To validate the surface elemental component and the chemical states of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is conducted, and the XPS analysis of Bi 4f, V 2p, Fe 2p, O 1s, and Mn 2p is shown in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4a, the full-scale spectrum of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly can indicate that the main elements on the surface of the sample are Bi, V, Fe, O, Mn. For Bi 4f, as shown in Fig. 4b, there are two fitting peaks of Bi 4f 5/2 and Bi 4f 7/2 at binding energy (BE) of 163.9 and 158.7 eV, demonstrating that bismuth is in the Bi3+ in BiVO4 lattice. The V 2p spectrum display two symmetric peaks with peaks centered at 524.1 and 516.4 eV, which are assigned to V 2p 1/2 and V 2p 3/2, respectively, manifesting that this element is existed as V 5+, as revealed in Fig. 4c. The Fe 2p XPS spectrum of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 is displayed in Fig. 4d. There are two characteristic peaks of Fe0 at 709.4 and 718.4 eV (Fig. 4d) in the spectrogram, representing the nano-zero-valent iron particles are
composited on the surface of the assembly [53]. However, two distinct peaks at approximately 724.4 and 711.1 eV are distributed to Fe 2p 1/2 and Fe 2p 3/2, respectively, which are linked to Fe 2+ and Fe 3+. It indicates that both Fe2+ and Fe3+ are present on the surface of nanozero-valent iron particles, which appear from the presence of Fe oxides. The spectrum of O 1s can be partition into three independent peaks, as shown in Fig. 4e. The leading peak of O 1s locates at 529.8 eV, which is ascribed to the surface lattice oxygen. The peaks located at 531.2 and 532.8 eV are attributed to the oxygen of hydroxyl species in the sample surface and O in the adsorbed water species, respectively. Furthermore, the Mn 2p XPS semaphores can be decomposed into three elements at binding energy of 641.8 and 653.5 eV (Fig. 4f), which can be ascribed to MnOx. This result indicates that x is between 1.5 and 2.0 because the inspected binding energies of the manganese oxides are between those of Mn2O3 and MnO2 [34]. In the light of the analysis and argument, it can be judged that MnOx and nano-zero-valent iron have been successfully introduced, and the ternary system has been successfully fabricated.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photocatalytic activity
sections.text:
To evaluate the excellent photocatalytic activity of BiVO4, MnOx/ BiVO4, Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4, 2,4-DCP and BPA are opted as the degradation stuff to inspect the catalytic function under the visible light irradiation. So as to obtain the best consequent of degradation of toxic pollutants, all of the tests are carried out under acidic conditions [12]. With the increase in pH, the oxidation potential of •OH is decreased. It ranges from 2.65 to 2.80 V in acidic conditions and reaches 1.90 V in neutral conditions, where the unrestrained energy of neutralization is not available, which indicates that %OH is an inferior oxidant at neutral surrounding than at acidic surrounding [54,55]. Another reason is that the decrease of Fe3+ is faster under the acidic conditions than in the neutral conditions [56]. As shown in Figs. 5a and S1, the line chart can evidently display the degradation ratio of the specimen every 30min. Before the photocatalytic degradation, the adsorption aptness is detected in the murk with 30min. The results show that the adsorption rates of the three composite samples are significantly enhanced. In especial, the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly demonstrates the best photocatalytic degradation ability, and the
degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP and BPA are ˜3.1 and 3.3 times higher than that of the pristine BiVO4, respectively. The single introduction of MnOx and Fe0 also improves the photocatalytic degradation ability of pristine BiVO4. The bar chart of Figs. 5b and S2 can be more intuitive to inspect the final degradation rate of 2,4-DCP and BPA. The 2,4-DCP and BPA photocatalytic degradation performance of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 are up to 95.4 and 91.4%, respectively. The degradation rates of 2,4-DCP for BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/BiVO4 are 30.9, 47.6 and 81.7%, respectively. And the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of BPA is 28.4, 41.8 and 72.6%, respectively. To further comprehend the photocatalytic degradation efficiency,
the reaction dynamics of degradation 2,4-DCP and BPA for as-synthesized photocatalysts were computed, and the noticeable reaction rate constant (k) values are shown in Figs. 5c and S3. The k of 2,4-DCP for BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 are 0.0020, 0.0037, 0.0098, and 0.0173min−1, and the constants of BPA are 0.0019, 0.0030, 0.0076, and 0.0145min−1, respectively. Contrasted with other samples, the k of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 is the highest, which is approximately 9 and 7 times higher than that of genuine BiVO4. The
above results indicate that Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly has the best photocatalytic degradation performance compared with other samples. The high photocatalytic performance of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly may be ascribed to the vast absorption extent of brightness and the photocatalytic coupling Fenton effect produces a large number of active species Furthermore, the oxidation cocatalyst MnOx is selectively photo-deposited on the {110} facets of BiVO4, which facilitates the separation of photogenerated carriers and quickens the carriers metastasis, thereby improving photocatalytic efficiency [38]. The reusability of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly is achieved by duplicating the degradation test 4 times on both pollutants. As is shown in Figs. 5d and S4, after 4 times test, the photocatalytic degradation performance has subtle changes, implying the prepared sample is fairly stable for photocatalysis. In addition, zero-valent iron is converted into other iron species
during the reaction to affect the components and stability of the photocatalyst. The element content and the valence of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 before and after four cycles photodegradation of 2,4-DCP is also tested by XPS. From Fig. S5, the full-scale spectrum of fresh and used Fe0/
MnOx/BiVO4 demonstrates that all of the main elements are well preserved. The Fe 2p XPS spectrum of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 before and after the photodegradation cycles is illustrated in Fig. S6. Comparing the spectra of fresh and used photocatalyst, the two characteristic peaks of Fe0 still exist, but the decrease of the peak area indicates that the content of Fe0 has varied. This result can be attributed to the formation of photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system during photodegradation, which transforms Fe0 to Fe2+ and Fe3+, and as the reaction proceeds, Fe0 is regenerated by photogenerated electrons reduction of iron ions. The consumption of Fe0 is suppressed. Therefore, the prepared sample is considerably steady for photocatalysis.

sections.heading: 3.4. Photocatalytic mechanism
sections.text:
UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) is adopted to censor the absorption function and band gaps of the samples in Fig. 6a. It can be seen that each sample displays the distinct absorption profile, and all of the samples show great absorption in the visible light region. For pure BiVO4, the absorption onset is located at around 550 nm, and the presence of MnOx enlarges the optical absorption limit from 550 to 600 nm. This may be due to the MnOx selective deposition on the {110} facet of BiVO4 and explains the presence of MnOx. Additionally, the color of sample is a concerning element of light absorption capability [57]. After adding the nano-zero-valent iron, the color altered from bright yellow of pure BiVO4 to blackish dark yellow of Fe0/ BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4. It can be clearly observed that the Fe0/ BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly has evidently raised absorption, not only in the visible district but also in the near-infrared district, which can redound to black color of coupling nano-zero-valent iron. The absorption intensity of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly is slightly lower than that of Fe0/ BiVO4. Furthermore, the values of band gap energies for different specimens are also computed and the consequents are shown in Fig. 6b. They can be the result of electronic transitions from the elevated valence band to the lowered conduction band, and the band gaps of BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 and Fe0/ BiVO4 are 2.44, 2.37, 2.10, and 1.84 eV, respectively. It is essential that the band gap of BiVO4 is effectively narrowed after the addition of MnOx and nano-
zero-valent iron, and the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly has the most suitable but not the narrowest band gap energy of 2.10 eV. A suitable narrow band gap can improve the efficiency of the light absorption, which is a key factor in increasing photocatalytic activity. Therefore, the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly demonstrates the best photocatalytic degradation efficiency. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) and transient photocurrent
response tests are performed to further analyze charge carrier generation and separation process of each sample. As can be seen from Fig. 6c, the EIS of BiVO4, MnOx/BiVO4, Fe0/ BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 can accurate and valid gauge electrical conductivity of charge carriers, and the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly demonstrates smaller semicircle radius than that of others, representing that Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 possesses a higher efficiency for charge separation. It's worth noting that the EIS semicircular radius of MnOx/BiVO4 is significantly smaller than that of Fe0/BiVO4, implying that selective deposition of MnOx and accumulation of holes are the main reasons for promoting charge separation efficiency. Corresponding to the EIS, the value of photocurrent can also sidelong incarnate the efficiency of charge separation, and the transient photocurrent responses of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 6d. It can be seen that the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly illustrates the highest photocurrent response intensity among these photocatalysts, which has a better ability to generate and separate photogenerated charge carriers. Similar to the results of EIS, the photocurrent value of the sample after MnOx deposition is significantly improved, indicating that the selective deposition of MnOx can accumulate holes to produce synergistic effect and effectively inhibit charge recombination. It is particularly notorious that there are a lot of main reactive
oxygen species participated in the photocatalytic oxidation reaction, such as h+, •OH and •O2−. To confirm the active species, which perform a primary role in the photocatalytic oxidation degradation of 2,4-DCP and BPA. The photocatalytic degradation of BPA is duplicated by adding the distinct scavenger agents. The benzoquinone (BQ), EDTA2Na and tert-butanol (TBA) were adopted to quench superoxide radicals (%O2−), photogenerated holes (h+), and hydroxyl radical (%OH), respectively. After adding scavenger, the photocatalytic reaction would be partly inhibited and the photocatalytic oxidation rate is lowered. As
shown in Fig. 7a, the efficiency of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 photodegradation BPA decreased by 43% after adding EDTA-2Na, which represented that h+ has an effect on the degradation of BPA. In addition, it can be seen that the effect of photodegradation efficiency after adding benzoquinone is minimal, which means that %O2− has little effect on the photocatalytic activity of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the degradation rate of BPA is significantly lower after adding tertbutanol. The results manifest that the %OH is the principal oxidative species in the photocatalytic reaction, and the order of active groups is %OH > h+> %O2−. As shown in Fig. 7b, the fluorescence semaphore emerges at about 425 nm, and the fluorescence strength of the Fe0/ MnOx/BiVO4 assembly is the strongest compared with other samples. This is powerful evidence that the composite of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly produces the most hydroxyl radicals, and this result is also identical with the consequences of previous degradation experiments. In order to confirm the photocatalytic mechanism, the DMPO-ESR
spin-trap technique is used to identify the types of active radicals during the catalytic process. From Fig. 7c, there is no DMPO-%OH response signal for BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 in darkness, indicating that no photocatalytic reaction occurs without light. As expected, typical signal peaks of BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 with a ratio of 1:2:2:1 were detected under illumination, representing that the %OH is formed during the photocatalytic reaction. It is worth noting that the signal intensity of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 is significantly higher than that of pure BiVO4, because the selective deposition of the co-oxidant MnOx on the {110} facet promotes charge separation to retain more holes and oxidize OH− to form %OH. At the same time, the formation of the photocatalysisFenton coupling system during the reaction also provides a large number of hydroxyl radicals. The DMPO-%O2− of BiVO4 and Fe0/MnOx/ BiVO4 are shown in Fig. 7d. In the dark, there is no peak denoting no •O2− production. After visible light illumination, the apparent ESR signal of •O2− emerged, whereas six peak are generated and attributed to the reduction of O2 by photo-generated electrons of BiVO4. Similar to %OH, the signal strength of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 is higher than that of BiVO4, because the photocatalysis-Fenton coupling system can also produce a certain amount of %O2−.In particular, the %OH signal intensity of Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 is significantly higher than that of %O2−, indicating that the concentration of %OH produced is higher than %O2−. Hence, the
ESR analysis reveals that the production of %OH and %O2− and the retention of more holes during photocatalysis promote the efficiency of photocatalytic degradation, and %OH plays a leading role, which is consistent with that reported in trapping experiment. Based on the above results and discussions, the charge transfer of the Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 assembly and the possible photocatalytic coupling-Fenton mechanism for degradation of pollutants are presented as schematically illustrated in Scheme 2. Under visible light irradiation, the photogenerated electrons and holes of BiVO4 can be separately accumulated on the {010} and {110} facets to achieve charge separation, and the MnOx as oxidation cocatalysts selective deposition on the {110} side can accumulate holes, in which the photogenerated holes can be further transferred to MnOx for the surface catalytic reactions to promote the oxidation reaction and charge separation. Electron accumulated on earth the {010} side of the BiVO4 immediately seizes dissolved oxygen and free hydrogen ions in aqueous medium, which lead to rapid production of H2O2 in the system. H2O2 and the free hydrogen ions are able to convert Fe0 particles coated with BiVO4 into Fe2+. Forming Fe2+ efficiently activate the H2O2 to produce %OH and then it is oxidized to Fe3+, and the Fe3+ react with hydrogen peroxide to produce Fe2+ and superoxide free radical (•O2−), which take shape typical cycling of Fe3+/Fe2+. In the process of this cycle, Fenton reaction significantly improves the estimate of active species and therefore effectively increases photocatalytic activity. At the same time, the pollutants can be effectively resolved into CO2 and H2O through the h+ with MnOx on the {110} facet of BiVO4.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, novel Fe0/MnOx/BiVO4 ternary assembly with planar selective deposition has been fabricated through hydrothermal and photo-deposition method. The assembly has proper narrow band gap of 2.10 eV and excellent charge separation, which effectively enhance photocatalytic activity. Under visible light irradiation, the photocatalytic degradation proportion of 2,4-DCP and BPA is up to 95.4 and 91.4% higher than the pure BiVO4 by 3.1 and 3.3 times, respectively. The introduction of nano-zero-valent iron make the material to constitute the photocatalytic coupling Fenton system, and the magnetic
